natural problem: What is the units digit of $7^7$ when expressed as an integer?
natural solution: If we are only interested in the units digit of a product of several numbers, we may drop any digits other than units digits as they will not affect the units digit of the product. Bringing in each factor one at a time, we find: \begin{tabular}{r}

The units digit of $\,7^1\,$ is 7, \\ $7\times7\,$ ends in 9, so the units digit of $\,7^2\,$ is 9, \\ $9\times7\,$ ends in 3, so the units digit of $\,7^3\,$ is 3, \\ $3\times7\,$ ends in 1, so the units digit of $\,7^4\,$ is 1, \\

$1\times7\,$ ends in 7, so the units digit of $\,7^5\,$ is 7, \\ $7\times7\,$ ends in 9, so the units digit of $\,7^6\,$ is 9, \\ $9\times7\,$ ends in 3, so the units digit of $\,7^7\,$ is $\,\boxed{3}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "7 ^ 7 = n"
shows  "n mod 10 = 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the units digit of $7^7$ when expressed as an integer? The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 If we are only interested in the units digit of a product of several numbers, we may drop any digits other than units digits as they will not affect the units digit of the product. Bringing in each factor one at a time, we find: \begin{tabular}{r}
 The units digit of $\,7^1\,$ is 7, \\ $7\times7\,$ ends in 9, so the units digit of $\,7^2\,$ is 9, \\ $9\times7\,$ ends in 3, so the units digit of $\,7^3\,$ is 3, \\ $3\times7\,$ ends in 1, so the units digit of $\,7^4\,$ is 1, \\
 $1\times7\,$ ends in 7, so the units digit of $\,7^5\,$ is 7, \\ $7\times7\,$ ends in 9, so the units digit of $\,7^6\,$ is 9, \\ $9\times7\,$ ends in 3, so the units digit of $\,7^7\,$ is $\,\boxed{3}$.
 \end{tabular}
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "7 ^ 7 = n"
shows  "n mod 10 = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the remainder when $7^7$ is divided by 10? The final answer is 3.

 *)

 proof-

a_1.informal problem: What is the remainder when $7^7$ is divided by 10? The final answer is 3.

(* ### Problem

 ### Proof
 If we are only interested in the units digit of a product of several numbers, we may drop any digits other than units digits as they will not affect the units digit of the product. Bringing in each factor one at a time, we find: \begin{tabular}{r}
 The units digit of $\,7^1\,$ is 7, \\ $7\times7\,$ ends in 9, so the units digit of $\,7^2\,$ is 9, \\ $9\times7\,$ ends in 3, so the units digit of $\,7^3\,$ is 3, \\ $3\times7\,$ ends in 1, so the units digit of $\,7^4\,$ is 1, \\

 \end{tabular}
 *)

theorem
fixes a :: int
